awd_titl_txt: Mechanism of Substrate Transformations by the Complex Iron Sulfur Molybdoenzyme (CISM) Family
awd_abstract_narration:
With this award, the Chemistry of Life Processes Program in the Chemistry Division is funding Dr. Partha Basu of Indiana University–Purdue University Indianapolis to investigate how the Complex Iron-Sulfur Molybdoenzyme (CISM) family of respiratory enzymes catalyze the reduction of a wide variety of chemicals. Respiration is an essential metabolic process that generates energy in all living systems. Many microorganisms utilize specialized enzymes to carry out anaerobic respiration where substrates such as nitrate, perchlorate, and dimethyl sulfoxide are reduced. These metabolic processes contribute to ecological diversity.  Biochemical, spectroscopic, computational, and kinetic methods are used to systematically study how the structure of the active site of these CISM enzymes allows them to display substrate selectivity. This project provides graduate students and postdoctoral fellows with specialized training in enzymology, spectroscopy, and computation. In addition, the research is integrated into an outreach program that introduces high school students to the study of enzymes and attracts first-year students who are not pursuing a science degree to science. A strong emphasis of the program is to use research to convey to students from groups underrepresented in STEM careers an appreciation for science. 
 
CISM enzymes are ubiquitous and play essential physiological roles in transforming different oxyanions. This research project uses periplasmic nitrate reductase as a model enzyme and develops several mutational variants of this enzyme where the coordination environment of molybdenum is systematically modified. The kinetic analyses of the enzyme variants help develop a quantitative picture for substrate selectivity. In addition, several residues in the catalytic pocket are identified as being involved in proton shuttling and substrate binding. Mutations of these residues provide valuable information about the mechanism of the reaction. The kinetic data are placed in the context of structural and spectroscopic properties of the enzyme. The proposed research provides new detailed insights into the substrate transformations catalyzed by members of the CISM family.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual Merit.

  • The CISM family processes various substrates, but quantitative data on substrate preference is limited, and the reasons for selectivity remain unclear. Molybdenum coordination is thought to affect catalytic activity, with the coordinating residue potentially influencing substrate preference. We used C. jejuni NapA as a model to study these effects, creating variants by replacing the molybdenum-coordinating cysteine with other amino acids. The resulting kinetic data provide quantitative insights into the role of this residue. Published in 2021: DOI: 10.1007/s00775-020-01833-9.
  • C. jejuni NapA contains a molybdenum cofactor (Moco) and a [4Fe4S] cluster, facilitating electron transfer from NapC → NapB → NapA via the [4Fe4S] cluster. A conserved lysine (K79) bridges Moco and the [4Fe4S] cluster through H-bonding. Mutation of K79 to Ala results in total activity loss, highlighting its catalytic role. Inhibition studies show cyanide inhibits NapA non-competitively, while thiocyanate and azide inhibit uncompetitively, without binding to the Mo-center, likely binding at the Lys site instead. Published in 2024: DOI://10.1007/s00775-024-02057-x.
  • Mo K-edge Extended X-ray Absorption Fine-Structure Spectroscopy (EXAFS) was used to examine wild-type C. jejuni NapA and its C176A variant. EXAFS data indicate an oxidized Mo(VI) hexacoordinate site in wild-type NapA, featuring one terminal oxo donor, four sulfur atoms from pyranopterin dithiolene ligands, and one sulfur from a conserved cysteine (C176). No terminal sulfido ligand was detected. In C176A, the active site is also hexacoordinate, with SCys replaced by a hydroxide or water ligand, as confirmed by EPR and Mo(V) analog studies. These findings highlight C176's essential role in nitrate-to-nitrite reduction without a terminal sulfido ligand. Published in 2024: DOI:// 10.1021/acs.inorgchem.4c01991
  • C. jejuni NapA is one of the most catalytically efficient NapA enzymes, with a kcat/Km of 1.74x106 M-1s-1, significantly higher than NapAs from C. sphaeroides and P. pantotrophus. Prepared under single turnover conditions, the singly reduced enzyme was examined by EPR spectroscopy, offering new insights into NapA spectra and structure. These findings enhance our understanding of nitrate reductase mechanisms, molybdenum coordination, and pyranopterin ligand roles in catalysis. This work is currently under review.
  • Sequence analysis shows that C. jejuni NapA, with multiple insertion sequences, is larger than other structurally characterized NapAs. We report the cryo-EM structure of C. jejuni NapA, the first from any ε-proteobacteria, revealing lysine-rich polypeptide insertions; three of which form part of the substrate channel. These insertions likely contribute to C. jejuni NapA's high nitrate affinity. While catalytic efficiency for non-native substrates (chlorate and perchlorate) is low, the high Km values confirm C. jejuni NapA’s evolutionary adaptation for nitrate. Structural comparison with other DMSOR family members suggests the proximal pterin’s role in electron transfer to the Mo center. A manuscript on this work is being prepared.
  • We investigated three proposed oxygen atom transfer (OAT) mechanisms in NapA-catalyzed nitrate reduction. Our recent study (Inorg. Chem. 2024, 63, 29, 13191–13196) identified a Mo(VI)=O species in nitrate-oxidized C. jejuni NapA. Here, we show that NapA can both reduce nitrate to nitrite and oxidize nitrite to nitrate, marking the first demonstration of reversible nitrate-nitrite interconversion by nitrate reductase. Using isotope labeling, mass spectrometry, and NMR, we present the first experimental evidence of OAT in both forward (nitrate reduction) and reverse (nitrite oxidation) reactions and propose a mechanism supported by experimental and computational data. A detailed manuscript is nearing completion.

 

Broader Impact.

   a) Promoting Teaching, Training, and Learning: Since 2020, the PI has trained 20 undergraduates in the PI’s lab, primarily in biochemical and molecular biology techniques. Of the 12 who graduated, six pursued PhDs, one entered medical school, and two joined industry roles. Five Project SEED students (all minorities) also received training, with four now in college and one completing high school. Among graduate students, one MS student entered industry, one began a postdoc, and PhD student, Mikayla Metzger, supported by this grant, will graduate next semester. Additionally, three postdocs benefited from the grant’s support, with two now in new roles.

b) Broadening Participation of Underrepresented Groups: Mikayla Metzger, a female graduate student, worked on this project. Nine of the 20 undergraduates were female, and four SEED students were Black female students.

c) Engaging First-Year Students in Research Careers: In the first-year "Windows of Science" class, practicing scientists—from graduate students to professors—shared their career journeys, highlighting the importance of research involvement. We plan to continue this initiative, encouraging speakers to emphasize their personal experiences to inspire students toward research careers.

 

 


Last Modified: 11/05/2024
Modified by: Partha Basu

The resulting kinetic data provide quantitative insights into the role of this residue. Published in 2021: DOI: 10.1007/s00775-020-01833-9.
C. jejuni NapA contains a molybdenum cofactor (Moco) and a [4Fe4S] cluster, facilitating electron transfer from NapC  NapB  NapA via the [4Fe4S] cluster. A conserved lysine (K79) bridges Moco and the [4Fe4S] cluster through H-bonding. Mutation of K79 to Ala results in total activity loss, highlighting its catalytic role. Inhibition studies show cyanide inhibits NapA non-competitively, while thiocyanate and azide inhibit uncompetitively, without binding to the Mo-center, likely binding at the Lys site instead. Published in 2024: DOI://10.1007/s00775-024-02057-x.
Mo K-edge Extended X-ray Absorption Fine-Structure Spectroscopy (EXAFS) was used to examine wild-type C. jejuni NapA and its C176A variant. EXAFS data indicate an oxidized Mo(VI) hexacoordinate site in wild-type NapA, featuring one terminal oxo donor, four sulfur atoms from pyranopterin dithiolene ligands, and one sulfur from a conserved cysteine (C176). No terminal sulfido ligand was detected. In C176A, the active site is also hexacoordinate, with SCys replaced by a hydroxide or water ligand, as confirmed by EPR and Mo(V) analog studies. These findings highlight C176's essential role in nitrate-to-nitrite reduction without a terminal sulfido ligand. Published in 2024: DOI:// 10.1021/acs.inorgchem.4c01991
C. jejuni NapA is one of the most catalytically efficient NapA enzymes, with a kcat/Km of 1.74x106 M-1s-1, significantly higher than NapAs from C. sphaeroides and P. pantotrophus. Prepared under single turnover conditions, the singly reduced enzyme was examined by EPR spectroscopy, offering new insights into NapA spectra and structure. These findings enhance our understanding of nitrate reductase mechanisms, molybdenum coordination, and pyranopterin ligand roles in catalysis. This work is currently under review.
Sequence analysis shows that C. jejuni NapA, with multiple insertion sequences, is larger than other structurally characterized NapAs. We report the cryo-EM structure of C. jejuni NapA, the first from any -proteobacteria, revealing lysine-rich polypeptide insertions; three of which form part of the substrate channel. These insertions likely contribute to C. jejuni NapA's high nitrate affinity. While catalytic efficiency for non-native substrates (chlorate and perchlorate) is low, the high Km values confirm C. jejuni NapAs evolutionary adaptation for nitrate. Structural comparison with other DMSOR family members suggests the proximal pterins role in electron transfer to the Mo center. A manuscript on this work is being prepared.
We investigated three proposed oxygen atom transfer (OAT) mechanisms in NapA-catalyzed nitrate reduction. Our recent study (Inorg. Chem. 2024, 63, 29, 1319113196) identified a Mo(VI)=O species in nitrate-oxidized C. jejuni NapA. Here, we show that NapA can both reduce nitrate to nitrite and oxidize nitrite to nitrate, marking the first demonstration of reversible nitrate-nitrite interconversion by nitrate reductase. Using isotope labeling, mass spectrometry, and NMR, we present the first experimental evidence of OAT in both forward (nitrate reduction) and reverse (nitrite oxidation) reactions and propose a mechanism supported by experimental and computational data. A detailed manuscript is nearing completion.






Broader Impact.


 a) Promoting Teaching, Training, and Learning: Since 2020, the PI has trained 20 undergraduates in the PIs lab, primarily in biochemical and molecular biology techniques. Of the 12 who graduated, six pursued PhDs, one entered medical school, and two joined industry roles. Five Project SEED students (all minorities) also received training, with four now in college and one completing high school. Among graduate students, one MS student entered industry, one began a postdoc, and PhD student, Mikayla Metzger, supported by this grant, will graduate next semester. Additionally, three postdocs benefited from the grants support, with two now in new roles.


b) Broadening Participation of Underrepresented Groups: Mikayla Metzger, a female graduate student, worked on this project. Nine of the 20 undergraduates were female, and four SEED students were Black female students.


c) Engaging First-Year Students in Research Careers: In the first-year "Windows of Science" class, practicing scientistsfrom graduate students to professorsshared their career journeys, highlighting the importance of research involvement. We plan to continue this initiative, encouraging speakers to emphasize their personal experiences to inspire students toward research careers.
